summary: This document appears to be a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) training presentation on suicide prevention in Special Housing Units (SHUs), focusing on managing high-risk inmates including those who are behaviorally disordered, mentally ill, sex offenders, or in protective custody. It outlines policies, risk factors, and management strategies such as double-celling and Suicide Risk Management Plans.
keyFacts: The document is a BOP training presentation dated October 10, 2018, focused on suicide prevention in locked units like SHUs.
It states that between 30% and 80% of inmate suicides annually occur on locked units, with single cells in these units being especially risky.
It recommends double-celling for all SHU inmates unless there is a compelling reason not to, to reduce isolation and suicide risk.

It identifies specific high-risk inmate groups: behaviorally disordered inmates (responsible for ~30% of SHU suicides), mentally ill inmates (30-60% of SHU suicides), sex offenders, and protective custody inmates.
It describes the implementation of a 'Suicide Risk Management Plan' as a collaborative, non-punitive strategy to increase inmate safety by decreasing self-harm behaviors.
